utterances: How did you deal with that with him?
I told him, you know, to ignore them, to tell them, well, why don't you come try it.
It's a lot harder than it looks.
It's a sport as much as an art form.
And also we told him, you know, he's being very smart.
He's in a room with beautiful ballet dancers as opposed to, you know, sweaty gross boys on a field.
And I understand that when he was in training that he found out that the training he'd gotten as a ballet dancer helped him as a soldier as well.
I think ballet and Marines are actually very closely tied.
You have the discipline.
You have the long hours of work.
You have the - ignoring pain and being exhausted and just - to keep on going.
Were you surprised when he decided to become a Marine?
Very much so.
Some Palestinians analysts say the reforms Farhat is seeking won't be easy.
Iyad Saraj, a prominent Gaza psychiatrist, says Mariam Farhat is an important symbol of resistance to Israel.
But he says most Palestinians don't want Hamas to make major changes in their way of life.
For the Palestinian Muslims, in general, although they are deeply believing in Islam, they are secular in outlook.
They want to see government that is not encouraging corruption, that can enforce the law and order, respect human rights, respect democratization, and open up to the other cultures.
I believe that Palestinian society is not for an Islamic government, as such.
But Farhat and her fellow Hamas parliament members disagree.
They say they were elected to deepen Palestinians' connection to Islam, and they say they will do whatever they can to accomplish this.
Linda Gradstein, NPR News.
Leaders of major technology companies here in the U.S.
are criticizing President Trump's executive order that bans immigrants from some Muslim countries.
As NPR's Laura Sydell reports, there are growing concerns that the order is going to hurt business.
Silicon Valley prides itself on its openness to immigrants.
And it's not just talk.
A study by the National Foundation for American Policy, a nonpartisan think tank, found that 51 percent of U.S.
startup companies worth more than a billion dollars were founded by immigrants.
Yesterday, at the San Francisco International Airport, hundreds of people showed up for the second day in a row to protest the Trump administration's executive order.
Joel Parish is an engineer at Apple.
He is not an immigrant, but he says many of his colleagues are.
It is a big concern.
And some of my best co-workers - the best engineers - are on immigrant visas or have spouses that are on immigrant visas.
And so I know they're extremely concerned about this.
And it's impacting our ability to travel and do business internationally.
We have a global presence.
In an email sent to Apple staff, CEO Tim Cook said the company had employees directly affected by the executive order, and it was offering help.
Cook said Apple would not exist without immigration.
In fact, its co-founder, Steve Jobs, was the son of a Syrian immigrant.
Google co-founder Sergey Brin is an immigrant who was born in the Soviet Union and fled to the U.S.
with his family as a child.
He showed up to yesterday's protest at the San Francisco airport.
And today, there were others here from his company.
Mani Varadarajan, a software engineer at Google, came to the U.S.
from India when he was a year old.
He says the Trump administration order was felt immediately at Google.
I did have a friend call me rather frantically - and not a very political friend, but he called me on Friday - who is a Google employee.
He manages people.
And two employees in his team were told that they shouldn't travel because there's a doubt as to whether they could come back if they did travel.
Until now, many tech leaders were keeping a low profile as to their thoughts on the Trump administration.
In December, leaders of the largest tech companies met with Trump, and it appeared friendly.
But Friday's executive order definitely changed that.
The CEO of Google, Sundar Pichai, is an immigrant and is critical of the Trump administration order.
In a memo to staff, he said it was painful to see the personal cost of it on colleagues.
Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg wrote, we need to keep this country safe, but we should do that by focusing on people who actually pose a threat.
The CEO of Microsoft, Satya Nadella, also an immigrant, said his company is committed to helping the 76 employees impacted by the ban.
The founders of the ride-hailing service Lyft, which has many immigrant drivers, will donate $1 million to the ACLU.
Even immigrant workers not directly covered by the ban say they feel afraid.
John Hanna is from Egypt, which isn't on the list.
For me and my wife, I'm concerned, too, if we had to travel at any time.
Would it be possible to come back?
Would it be a problem with expanding the ban to include Egypt, as well?
Hanna says he knows people who were out of the country when the ban came down, and now they can't get back into the U.S.
For its part, the Trump administration says implementation of the travel ban has been a massive success story.
Laura Sydell, NPR News, San Francisco.
(SOUNDBITE OF MAKANA'S ""NA PO'O KA LA"")
This is TALK OF THE NATION: SCIENCE FRIDAY.
I'm Ira Flatow.
Just over 30 years ago, a group of engineers, hackers, computer enthusiasts met in what today we call Silicon Valley.
It was a regular meeting of the Homebrew Computer Club: a discussion of chips, wires, the offerings of a growing number of electronics manufacturers.
But at one meeting in 1975, a club member named Steve Wozniak set up a computer he had designed and built on his own.
It had features that no one had ever seen before, features like a keyboard.
You could type on it instead of having to flip toggle switches or deal with punch cards.
It had a TV screen, not a paper tape or a printout.
And it was what today we know as the Apple I, and it sparked a revolution in computing, starting to put the personal into personal computers.
Steve Wozniak went on to co-found Apple Computer with Steve Jobs, where he became known as the driving engineering force behind the company's innovative early designs.
And Steve Wozniak, or as the Woz, as he's been called recently, meaning the last 30 years.
He's co-founder of Apple Computer.
He's the founder and CEO of Wheels of Zeus.
I'm hoping he'll talk about that a little bit.
He's also co-author with Gina Smith of a new book called iWoz: From the Computer Geek to Cult Icon: How I Invented the Personal Computer, Co-Founded Apple, and Had Fun Doing It.
It's just out from Norton.
And I know that having fun is one of Steve Wozniak's prime realities about life, is it not, Steve?
It sure is, yeah.
(Soundbite of laughter)
I've been having a lot of fun everyday.
You know, pranks, jokes.
But it actually started with a lifetime philosophy.

When you're about 20 years old, you kind of think out - I figured out that it was better - less good to be successful and better to have a laughing life, laugh more than you frown all through your life.
Because on the day you die, which one would you have said had the happier life, the better life?
And so I put a lot of humor in my life.
Mm-hmm.
Britain was (unintelligible) than many countries in that respect.
Some countries still have to go through that stage.
Okay, kids, this has nothing to do with the real Santa Claus.
But sometimes mommy and daddy like to play pretend Santa.
And in Germany - that's a country in Europe where some people think Santa goes first - anyway, the Germans had a Santa contest.
And as NPR's Emily Harris reports, the winner is a 42-year-old TV news reporter named Oliver Deuker.
(Soundbite of contest)
The town of Celle was on a search for Santa Claus.
It was one of those holiday events that could warm your heart or could turn your stomach.

A local band played as, in front of Celle's grand medieval castle, dozens of Santas in red and white earned points for pushing wooden sleds piled with presents across the lawn, for tossing packages down a fake chimney, and for racing to wrap three presents - nicely - in just three minutes.
Unidentified Woman #1: Funf, fier, zwei, zwei, ein, doch...
It's all in the Christmas spirit, says organizer Alex Haas.
There are too many Santa Clauses running always in the street.
The children are not sure if this is the real Santa Claus or not.
So we said we have to find out, we have to explain to the children.
Today we will show you the right and the only and the real Santa in Celle.
(Soundbite of bell)
The Santas made nails for reindeer shoes at a real forge.
They rode a mechanical reindeer until the guy controlling the joystick tossed them off.
(Soundbite of laughter)
The Santas laughed.
(Soundbite of Santas laughing)
With recruits from the small audience, they sang.
(Soundbite of Santas singing in German)
Naturally, all Santas were tested on how well they comfort children.
(Soundbite of Santa)
The grand prize was cash, $2,500, and for the ladies competing in the Santa's helper contest, an Egyptian vacation for two.
It was pure Christmas meets commercialism, but in kind of a sweet way.
The phone book company provided red robes for competitors who didn't have their own.
Imagine Santa with the yellow pages written on his back.
Organizer Haas.
Of course, we do it to bring the people to the wonderful city and to see, frankly, maybe a little bit funny action in December.
Of course, we need some partners who help us to pay for everything at the end.
Of course, we need.
But no, we want to - to keep it on a nice, on a friendly, on a Christmas great time, you know.
As the winners were announced, the bells of Celle's 13th century church began to ring, and rang, and rang, and rang, and rang.
(Soundbite of bells ringing)
